Home Front 1914-1918 - How Britain Survived the Great War 
The National Archives | 2006 | ISBN: 1903365813 | English | 224 pages | PDF | 73.3 MB

Not only did families risk their fathers and sons in active combat, but every member of society was mobilized in some way to contribute to the war effort. In the course of these eventful years the population experienced rationing, shortages, aerial bombing, thousands more women in work (known as Ã¢â‚¬ËœdilutionÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ of the workplace!), industrial unrest, a large influx of foreign refugees, and a host of other shocks.
